          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        11. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (256 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        12. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (247 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/ HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:49 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (203 bytes) 
          <title>HTTP Parameter Pollution Example</title>

<a href="?pp=12">check</a><br/>

<hr>
<a href='http://blog.mindedsecurity.com/2009/05/client-side-http-parameter-pollution.html'>Original article</a>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        13. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/?pp=12
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (258 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/?pp=12 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:55 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (383 bytes) 
          <title>HTTP Parameter Pollution Example</title>

<a href="?pp=12">check</a><br/>
<a href="params.php?p=valid&pp=12">link1</a><br/><a href="params.php?p=valid&pp=12">link2</a><br/><form action="params.php?p=valid&pp=12"><input type=submit name=aaaa/></form><br/>
<hr>
<a href='http://blog.mindedsecurity.com/2009/05/client-side-http-parameter-pollution.html'>Original article</a>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        14. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/params.php?p=valid&pp=12
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (282 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/params.php?p=valid&pp=12 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/hpp/?pp=12
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:43:00 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (7 bytes) 
          valid12
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        15. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/images/logo.gif
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

z5!Q5qS4139r8x54a*qD
@2s@ !(a5tg{80W$W8\"	]`C?<>W6qA2;Ct@␀A/R␀BHY6!@␀?{8 $0/x8HyM@8ArK.K0sL24L4TsM6t/␀;
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        16. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/images/remark.gif
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (274 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/images/remark.gif HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/guestbook.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (236 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:52 GMT
Content-Type: image/gif
Content-Length: 79
Last-Modified: Wed, 11 May 2011 10:27:46 GMT
Connection: keep-alive
ETag: "4dca64a2-4f"
Accept-Ranges: bytes
          Response body (79 bytes) 
          GIF89a␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!␀␀␀␀␀,␀␀␀␀␀␀␀&y
dJVLimQe4Bl*Q␀␀;
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        17. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/index.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

      <object classid="clsid:D27CDB6E-AE6D-11cf-96B8-444553540000" codebase="http://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,29,0" width="107" height="66">
        <param name="movie" value="Flash/add.swf">
        <param name=quality value=high>
        <embed src="Flash/add.swf" quality=high pluginspage="http://www.macromedia.com/shockwave/download/index.cgi?P1_Prod_Version=ShockwaveFlash" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="107" height="66"></embed>
      </object>
    </p>
  </div> 
</div> 

<!--end navbar --> 
<div id="siteInfo">  <a href="http://www.acunetix.com">About Us</a> | <a href="privacy.php">Privacy Policy</a> | <a href="mailto:wvs@acunetix.com">Contact Us</a> | <a href="/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/">Shop</a> | <a href="/hpp/">HTTP Parameter Pollution</a> | &copy;2019
  Acunetix Ltd 
</div> 
    
    
<br> 
<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        18. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?artist=1
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (289 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?artist=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php?artist=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:59 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (7994 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>pictures</title>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css">
<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<script language="JavaScript" type="text/JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);
//-->
</script>

</head>

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        19. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?artist=2
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (289 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?artist=2 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/artists.php?artist=2
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:59 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (5193 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        20. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?artist=3
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

	<td align="right">
		</td>
	</tr></table>
  </div> 
</div> 
<!-- end masthead --> 

<!-- begin content -->
<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="content_rgn" -->

	</div>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<!--end content -->

  Acunetix Ltd 
</div> 
<br> 
<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        21. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (280 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/categories.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:50 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (7880 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>pictures</title>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css">
<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->

<!--
function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);
//-->
</script>

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        22. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=2
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (280 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=2 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/categories.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Alert tags

          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. <div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>

<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        24. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=4
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (280 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=4 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/categories.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:51 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (4699 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>pictures</title>

    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);
//-->
</script>

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        25. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/login.php
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (252 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/login.php HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes)

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        26. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (260 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/ HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:49 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (975 bytes) 
          <html>
<div id="content">
	<div class='product'><table><tr><td width='180px'><img src='images/1.jpg'></td><td width='400px'><a href='Details/network-attached-storage-dlink/1/'>Network Storage D-Link DNS-313 enclosure 1 x SATA</a></td><td width='50px' bgcolor='#F8F8F8'><a href='Details/network-attached-storage-dlink/1/'>Price<br>359 &euro;</a></td></table></tr></div><div class='product'><table><tr><td width='180px'><img src='images/2.jpg'></td><td width='400px'><a href='Details/web-camera-a4tech/2/'>Web Camera A4Tech PK-335E</a></td><td width='50px' bgcolor='#F8F8F8'><a href='Details/web-camera-a4tech/2/'>Price<br>10 &euro;</a></td></table></tr></div><div class='product'><table><tr><td width='180px'><img src='images/3.jpg'></td><td width='400px'><a href='Details/color-printer/3/'>Laser Color Printer HP LaserJet M551dn, A4</a></td><td width='50px' bgcolor='#F8F8F8'><a href='Details/color-printer/3/'>Price<br>812 &euro;</a></td></table></tr></div></div>
</html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        27. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/BuyProduct-1/
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (332 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/BuyProduct-1/ HTTP/1.1

          Response body (100 bytes) 
          <div>Thanks for buying <b> Network Storage D-Link DNS-313 enclosure 1 x SATA</b><br><br></div>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        28. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/BuyProduct-2/
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

3hQ@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@	KE␀RR@Q@	KE␀R@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@Q@
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        35. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/images/3.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (290 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/images/3.jpg HTTP/1.1

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        36. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/RateProduct-1.html
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (337 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/RateProduct-1.html HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/Mod_Rewrite_Shop/Details/network-attached-storage-dlink/1/
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:43:00 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (100 bytes) 
          <div>Thanks for rating <b> Network Storage D-Link DNS-313 enclosure 1 x SATA</b><br><br></div>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

        <param name="movie" value="Flash/add.swf">
        <param name=quality value=high>
        <embed src="Flash/add.swf" quality=high pluginspage="http://www.macromedia.com/shockwave/download/index.cgi?P1_Prod_Version=ShockwaveFlash" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="107" height="66"></embed>
      </object>
    </p>
  </div> 
</div> 

<!--end navbar --> 
<div id="siteInfo">  <a href="http://www.acunetix.com">About Us</a> | <a href="privacy.php">Privacy Policy</a> | <a href="mailto:wvs@acunetix.com">Contact Us</a> | &copy;2019
  Acunetix Ltd 
</div> 
<br> 
<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        40. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=2
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (283 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=2 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:56 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (6368 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>picture details</title>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css">
<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->
<script language="javascript1.2">
<!--
	function popUpWindow(URLStr, left, top, width, height)
	{
	  window.open(URLStr, 'popUpWin', 'toolbar=no,location=no,directories=no,status=no,menub ar=no,scrollbar=no,resizable=no,copyhistory=yes,width='+width+',height='+height+',left='+left+', top='+top+',screenX='+left+',screenY='+top+'');
	}
-->
</script>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<script language="JavaScript" type="text/JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);
//-->
</script>

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        41. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=3
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

<!--end content -->

<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>
</div>
</div>
</body>
<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        43. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=5
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (283 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/product.php?pic=5 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (200 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:57 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (6382 bytes) 
          <!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
"http://www.w3.org/TR/html4/loose.dtd">
<html><!-- InstanceBegin template="/Templates/main_dynamic_template.dwt.php" codeOutsideHTMLIsLocked="false" -->
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=iso-8859-2">

<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="document_title_rgn" -->
<title>picture details</title>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css" type="text/css">
<!-- InstanceBeginEditable name="headers_rgn" -->
<script language="javascript1.2">
<!--
	function popUpWindow(URLStr, left, top, width, height)
	{
	  window.open(URLStr, 'popUpWin', 'toolbar=no,location=no,directories=no,status=no,menub ar=no,scrollbar=no,resizable=no,copyhistory=yes,width='+width+',height='+height+',left='+left+', top='+top+',screenX='+left+',screenY='+top+'');
	}
-->
</script>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<script language="JavaScript" type="text/JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);
//-->
</script>

          X-Content-Type-Options

	<h2 id='pageName'>Thing</h2><div class='story'><p><a href='showimage.php?file=./pictures/6.jpg' target='_blank'><img style='cursor:pointer' border='0' align='center' src='showimage.php?file=./pictures/6.jpg&size=160' width='160' height='100'></a><h3>Short description</h3><p>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit. 	function popUpWindow(URLStr, left, top, width, height)
	{
	  window.open(URLStr, 'popUpWin', 'toolbar=no,location=no,directories=no,status=no,menub ar=no,scrollbar=no,resizable=no,copyhistory=yes,width='+width+',height='+height+',left='+left+', top='+top+',screenX='+left+',screenY='+top+'');
	}
-->
</script>
<!-- InstanceEndEditable -->
<script language="JavaScript" type="text/JavaScript">
<!--
function MM_reloadPage(init) {  //reloads the window if Nav4 resized
  if (init==true) with (navigator) {if ((appName=="Netscape")&&(parseInt(appVersion)==4)) {
    document.MM_pgW=innerWidth; document.MM_pgH=innerHeight; onresize=MM_reloadPage; }}
  else if (innerWidth!=document.MM_pgW || innerHeight!=document.MM_pgH) location.reload();
}
MM_reloadPage(true);

</script>

</head>

<div style="background-color:lightgray;width:100%;text-align:center;font-size:12px;padding:1px">
<p style="padding-left:5%;padding-right:5%"><b>Warning</b>: This is not a real shop. This is an example PHP application, which is intentionally vulnerable to web attacks. It is intended to help you test Acunetix. It also helps you understand how developer errors and bad configuration may let someone break into your website. You can use it to test other tools and your manual hacking skills as well. Tip: Look for potential SQL Injections, Cross-site Scripting (XSS), and Cross-site Request Forgery (CSRF), and more.</p>

<!-- InstanceEnd --></html>
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        46. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/secured/style.css
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (280 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/secured/style.css HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/secured/newuser.php
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (239 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:43:03 GMT
Content-Type: text/css
Content-Length: 5482
Last-Modified: Wed, 11 May 2011 10:27:44 GMT
Connection: keep-alive
ETag: "4dca64a0-156a"
Accept-Ranges: bytes
          Response body (5482 bytes) 
          body{
	font-family: Arial,sans-serif;
	color: #333333;
	line-height: 1.166;	
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}

a:link, a:visited{
	color: #006699;
	text-decoration: none;
}

a:hover {
	text-decoration: underline;
}

h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {
	font-family: Arial,sans-serif;
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}

h1{
 font-family: Verdana,Arial,sans-serif;
 font-size: 120%;
 color: #334d55;
}

h2{
 font-size: 114%;
 color: #006699;
}

h3{
 font-size: 100%;
 color: #334d55;
}

h4{
 font-size: 100%;
 font-weight: normal;
 color: #333333;
}

h5{
 font-size: 100%;
 color: #334d55;
}

ul{
 list-style-type: square;
}

ul ul{
 list-style-type: disc;
}

ul ul ul{
 list-style-type: none;
}

label{
 font: bold 100% Arial,sans-serif;
 color: #334d55;
}
				

/***********************************************/
/* Layout Divs                                 */
/***********************************************/

#masthead{
	margin: 0;
	padding: 10px 0px;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #cccccc;
	width: 100%;
}

#navBar{
	margin: 0 79% 0 0;
	padding: 0px;
	background-color: #eeeeee;
	border-right: 1px solid #ccc;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #ccc;
}

#content{
  float:right;
	width: 75%;
	margin: 0;
	padding: 0 3% 0 0;
}


/***********************************************/
/*Component Divs                               */
/***********************************************/

#siteName{
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
}


/*************** #pageName styles **************/

#pageName{
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
}


/************* #globalNav styles **************/

#globalNav{
color: #cccccc;
padding: 0px 0px 0px 10px;
white-space: nowrap;
}
/* 'nowrap' prevents links from line-wrapping if there are too many to fit in one line
   this will force a horizontal scrollbar if there isn't enough room for all links
   remove rule or change value to 'normal' if you want the links to line-wrap */

#globalNav img{
 display: block;
}

#globalNav a {
	font-size: 90%;
	padding: 0px 4px 0px 0px; 
}


/************* #breadCrumb styles *************/

#breadCrumb{
	font-size: 80%;
	padding: 5px 0px 5px 10px;
}


/************** .feature styles ***************/

.feature{
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 10px;
	font-size: 80%;
}

.feature h3{
	padding: 30px 0px 5px 0px;
	text-align: center;
}

.feature img{
	float: left;
	padding: 0px 10px 0px 0px;
	margin: 0 5px 5px 0;
}
/* adjust margins to change separation between the feature image and text flowing around it */


/************** .story styles *****************/

.story{
	clear: both;
	padding: 10px 0px 0px 10px;
	font-size: 80%;
	background-color:#FFFFFF;
}

.story p{
	padding: 0px 0px 10px 0px;
	background-color:#FFFFFF;
}

/************* #siteInfo styles ***************/

#siteInfo{
	clear: both;
	border: 1px solid #cccccc;
	font-size: 75%;
	color: #cccccc;
	padding: 10px 10px 10px 10px;
	margin-top: -1px;
}
/* negative top margin pulls siteinfo up so its top border overlaps (and thus lines up with)
	the bottom border of the navBar in cases where they "touch" */

#siteInfo img{
	padding: 4px 4px 4px 0px;
	vertical-align: middle;
}


/************* #search styles ***************/

#search{
	padding: 5px 0px 5px 10px;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #cccccc;
	font-size: 90%;
}

#search form{
 margin: 0px;
 padding: 0px;
}

#search label{
	display: block;
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
}


/*********** #navBar link styles ***********/

#navBar ul a:link, #navBar ul a:visited {display: block;}
#navBar ul {list-style: none; margin: 0; padding: 0;}

/* hack to fix IE/Win's broken rendering of block-level anchors in lists */
#navBar li {border-bottom: 1px solid #EEE;}

/* fix for browsers that don't need the hack */
html>body #navBar li {border-bottom: none;}


/*********** #sectionLinks styles ***********/

#sectionLinks{
	position: relative;
	margin: 0px;
	padding: 0px;
	border-bottom: 1px solid #cccccc;
	font-size: 90%;
}

#sectionLinks h3{
	padding: 10px 0px 2px 10px;
}

	padding: 2px 0px 2px 10px;
	border-top: 1px solid #cccccc;
	width: 100%;
  voice-family: "\"}\""; 
  voice-family:inherit;
	width: auto;
}

#sectionLinks a:visited{
	border-top: 1px solid #cccccc;
	padding: 2px 0px 2px 10px;
}

#sectionLinks a:hover{
	border-top: 1px solid #cccccc;
	background-color: #dddddd;
	padding: 2px 0px 2px 10px;
}

	margin: 0px;

	font-size: 90%;
}

	padding: 10px 0px 2px 0px;
}

	display: block;

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        47. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file='%20+%20pict.item(0).firstChild.nodeValue%20+%20'
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

          X-Content-Type-Options

This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

,cz&NA<lE` 5^gCy_$@Xjd+"$$CR*$<@8a91d`OEAg#%M!f5@0N3B(]P(J
.(2
7]V4./+k?7@ Hlb[='%_8\|0/thJUQ'Oay8
T7␀␀␀!.(V`fsh)PT?
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        49. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/1.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/1.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:57 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (12426 bytes) 
          ␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀␀C␀


(=8/Z<CN4m^d(WX␀wMTJ. 	khv\$QU^71@[i0XKj0)ekuot&N?X3c}5_86+s^9eSNk7q␀

!
,cz&NA<lE` 5^gCy_$@Xjd+"$$CR*$<@8a91d`OEAg#%M!f5@0N3B(]P(J
.(2
7]V4./+k?7@ Hlb[='%_8\|0/thJUQ'Oay8
T7␀␀␀!.(V`fsh)PT?
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        50. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/2.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/2.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:56 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1
          Response body (3324 bytes) 
          ␀JFIF␀␀␀␀␀␀␀C␀

          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        51. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/2.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.

!t␀)4(p\MVA9	6;4ju8N$-QbA^);␀&␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀! 0A#1"Ca␀?KdeeY~I(b_S\{1]ec{6j"Blm#rDd)
['e^!d3m5<)>-S50D~+Zyr#1K;-;#!dld?,,g_#~,S,EY{IO36{Y	6F#LdEX␀"␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀ @!01QABa␀?P=8N#(S|h((-9~
"t5>j%8-$Cj'"j+q␀ ␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!P`p1␀ @Q␀␀?R*B0E8&␀$␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀! 10@APQaq␀␀?!Z?Oq99!
\EG>F?BBa$-#xcV^LK>mB?s|c}Y*4 r2HMG@,CX
_dh4&+XaiF=B^<}3~*fC#e0VuZ3>&MTr3l$=_~GzZz"d>'F6!#X22Mq~&Balr␀"ah!4$(kXM!␀␀␀␀␀␀y}}_␀U}␀Ip2}}{o@w}}>H_5@C}}}B`␀}}.)␀␀␀bOnt`-@␀␀␀␀␀␀Gl~8q␀␀␀␀	'A.({cg
18/v{}H\w		u␀'␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1AQ 0aq␀??PEM48swe~b#uYCM}HA67Y%Ae%cyd9ZdgsAslA9Zq<b`mlS> >~␀.?	8x8hZ}G{bqli9uN}z.g/-c5.N?d-;cbG(I*q;,␀|I
K jvV%Ye-␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀! 01a@Q␀?-,,xO[x}G8	wfyid<␀$,PR& <eGxy<"j3xYEs,,%qIe2,eY'N2␀Eu%A9,Y␀%␀␀␀␀␀␀␀␀!1 AQa0@q␀␀?	XQ_P2.9K%8KjW
Ytpo8e/_(W@
WxNRDcV2uF|bs9Kl
zJz{Z9 Q"Wpn=//@3? E(OB_v{utn[z␀&G~Gxs	_u*T	Ry`A␀q+	RJ~,T _GFbq/TN$
SBFEUw7>l\ZX(rmg(H14$*h-w8C|hv+`v_DSzQ>8#v4eSq-&
hdcA\ BhTnw4\|KV8aY<NDN`RbV,]\x%|(NhTQ'3BWBWDws;9 a(X);|e.(RRJ*TD `dx"DWRp]\P,␀A{P&!;9&bDDfbf[␀1c␀(%}TK␀d0`Em^E^* R"Kj5)c )4P7
q>JzAZJ
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        52. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (301 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Pragma: no-cache
Cache-Control: no-cache
Referer: http://testphp.vulnweb.com/listproducts.php?cat=1
          Request body (0 bytes)
          Response
          Status line and header section (186 bytes) 
          HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx/1.19.0
Date: Thu, 20 Jan 2022 18:42:56 GMT
Content-Type: image/jpeg
Connection: keep-alive
X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40-38+ubuntu20.04.1+deb.sury.org+1

!ZS@whCNl	"@w3iR`x?
          Parameter 
          X-Content-Type-Options
          Solution

          Ensure that the application/web server sets the Content-Type header appropriately, and that it sets the X-Content-Type-Options header to 'nosniff' for all web pages.

          If possible, ensure that the end user uses a standards-compliant and modern web browser that does not perform MIME-sniffing at all, or that can be directed by the web application/web server to not perform MIME-sniffing.
        53. GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg&size=160
          Alert tags
          • OWASP_2021_A05
          • OWASP_2017_A06
          Alert description

          The Anti-MIME-Sniffing header X-Content-Type-Options was not set to 'nosniff'. This allows older versions of Internet Explorer and Chrome to perform MIME-sniffing on the response body, potentially causing the response body to be interpreted and displayed as a content type other than the declared content type. Current (early 2014) and legacy versions of Firefox will use the declared content type (if one is set), rather than performing MIME-sniffing.
          Other info

          This issue still applies to error type pages (401, 403, 500, etc.) as those pages are often still affected by injection issues, in which case there is still concern for browsers sniffing pages away from their actual content type.

          At "High" threshold this scan rule will not alert on client or server error responses.
          Request
          Request line and header section (310 bytes) 
          GET http://testphp.vulnweb.com/showimage.php?file=./pictures/3.jpg&size=160 HTTP/1.1
Host: testphp.vulnweb.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
